head.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the top part of your body that has your face at the front and is supported by your neck
head.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: He kissed the top of her head.
Alan fell asleep as soon as he put his head on the pillow.
They dived head first into the water.
She was dressed in black from head to toe  (=over all her body).
He still has a full head of hair  (=has all his hair, even though he is getting rather old).
head.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The problem only exists inside his head.
I can’t do those figures in my head.
Use your head to work out the answer.
Jackie said the first thing that came into her head.
‘It’s over, Jake, ’ she said. ‘Try and get that into your head.’
At about two in the morning, Alan took it into his head to go for a swim.
take/get it into your head (to do something)
Try to put it out of your head for the time being.
get/put something out of your head
What’s put that idea into her head?
I just can’t get my head round what’s been going on here.
head.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to remain calm and sensible in a difficult or frightening situation
head.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: We need a candidate who can keep his or her head even when clients get aggressive.
Get to sleep early tonight – you’ll need to keep a clear head tomorrow at the trial.
head.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to become unable to behave calmly or sensibly in a difficult or frightening situation
head.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: You’ll be OK as long as you don’t lose your head and forget he’s the real enemy.
head.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to be sensible and able to deal with difficult situations
head.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: He wondered what Gemma thought about it all. She seemed to have her head screwed on.
head.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a leader or person in charge of a group or organization
head waiter/chef/gardener etc (=the person in charge of a group of waiters etc)
head.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: You should discuss the matter with your head of department.
A meeting of Commonwealth heads of state will be held next month.
head.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: the person in charge of a school
head.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: From now on all violent incidents should be reported directly to the head.
head.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: the front or the most important position
head.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: At the head of the table (=the place where the most important person sits) sat the senior partners.
Jenny marched proudly at the head of the procession.
The band of soldiers marched into the yard, their defeated captain at their head.
head.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: used in particular phrases to talk about someone being crazy or very stupid
head.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: People going out in conditions like this need their heads examined.
If I walk in looking like that, they’ll think I’m not right in the head.
You must be off your head if you think that.
head.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: the place where a river, valley etc begins
head.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: the top of a plant where its flowers or leaves grow
head.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: She was outside cutting the dead heads off the roses.
head.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: the length of a head, used to measure height or distance
head.translation[0].definitions[11].note: by a (short) head (=used to say that a horse won or lost a race but only by a small amount)
head.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: She saw her father, a head above the rest of the crowd.
head.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: the wide end of a long narrow tool or piece of equipment
head.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: the layer of small white bubbles on the top of a glass of beer
head.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: a piece of equipment that changes information on something magnetic, such as a recording tape or computer hard disk, into electrical messages that electronic equipment can use
head.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: a high area of land that sticks out into the sea – used in names
head.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: the centre of a swollen spot on your skin
head.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: turn your head
John turned his head to look at the boy.
shake your head
‘It’s too much, ’ he said, shaking his head.
nod your head
The audience nodded their heads enthusiastically.
somebody’s head hurts/aches/throbs
Her head was throbbing and she needed to lie down.
raise/lift your head
Tom raised his head to listen, then went back to his book.
bow/bend/lower your head
He bowed his head and tried not not to look at her.
hang your head
She hung her head, not sure how to reply.
scratch your head
He scratched his head and started looking through the drawers again.
cock your head
The big dog cocked his head to one side and raised his ears.
The sun beat down on her bare head.
bald
His bald head shone with sweat.
somebody’s blonde/dark/grey etc head
I saw my son’s blond head sticking out from the car window.
head + NOUN
head injury
Wearing a helmet reduces the risk of head injuries.
head.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to go or travel towards a particular place, especially in a deliberate way
head.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: It’s about time we were heading home.
We headed south towards the capital.
The ship was heading for Cuba.
head.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to be in charge of a team, government, organization etc
head.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: David was asked to head up the technical team.
an interim government headed by the former prime minister
head.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to be at the top of a list or group of people or things
head.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The movie heads the list of Oscar nominations.
head.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if a page is headed with a particular name, title, image etc, it has it on the top
head.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to be at the front of a line of people
head.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: a procession headed by the Queen
head.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: to hit the ball with your head, especially in football
head.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: the pithead  (=the top of a coal mine)
a letterhead  (=a name and address printed at the top of a letter)
head.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: the leader or person in charge of a group, organization, or part of an organization
head.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The head of each division is responsible for its operating performance.
Stone was head of corporate finance at Coopers & Lybrand.
Work is divided into different areas and is supervised by section heads.
head.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Any cash received must be double-checked by the head receptionist.
head.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to be able to make sensible and PROFITABLE business decisions
head.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: A conference for 70 people will work out at around £30 a head per day.
Expenditure per head on training had been growing rapidly.
head.translation[3].definitions[4].defin: if you deal with a problem head on, you deal with it in a very brave and direct way
head.translation[3].definitions[4].examp: The issue has to be tackled head on.
head.translation[3].definitions[5].defin: if two companies compete head on, they each try to be successful selling the same product or service
head.translation[3].definitions[5].examp: Instead of trying to compete head on with stores like Our Price and HMV, he moved down-market, stocking cheaper CDs and tapes.
head.translation[3].definitions[6].defin: to have an advantage that helps you to be successful
head.translation[3].definitions[6].examp: Banks will have a head start over their non-banking rivals in selling products in this new market.
have/be given a head start over
head.translation[3].definitions[7].defin: to only just manage to keep your company in business or live on the income you earn
head.translation[3].definitions[7].examp: These are savings that defence companies have to make to keep their heads above water.
head.translation[3].definitions[8].defin: if you go over the head of your BOSS (=the person who you normally take orders from at work), you ask his or her boss something instead of asking him or her directly
head.translation[3].definitions[8].examp: My boss was angry because I went over his head to the department manager.
head.translation[3].definitions[9].defin: used to say that someone will lose their job or be punished for a mistake they have made
head.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: to be in charge of a group, an organization, or part of an organization
head.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: if a page is headed with a particular word or sentence, it has it at the top
head.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: The three columns are headed ‘budget’, ‘actual’ and ‘variance’.
head.translation[4].definitions[2].defin: if a share price, currency etc heads north, it rises in value. If it heads south, it falls in value
head.translation[4].definitions[2].examp: Right now, the rouble is heading south.
